Answer: This startup hasn't failed yet, but it may if we Indians don't change our mind set.Bounce, a startup which runs in Bangalore provides dockless scooters on rent. Dockless means that the scooters would be parked on a public parking or a road which doesn't have much traffic, and a person who needs one can find it on the Bounce app and start it with an OTP.He can then park it wherever he wants and the next person would pick it up from there.So, as there's no checking being done on who has rented the scooter and is it parked safely or not this is what we have done to the scooters.A bounce scooter tThis startup hasn't failed yet, but it may if we Indians don't change our mind set.Bounce, a startup which runs in Bangalore provides dockless scooters on rent. Dockless means that the scooters would be parked on a public parking or a road which doesn't have much traffic, and a person who needs one can find it on the Bounce app and start it with an OTP.He can then park it wherever he wants and the next person would pick it up from there.So, as there's no checking being done on who has rented the scooter and is it parked safely or not this is what we have done to the scooters.A bounce scooter thrown on the road.Someone has parked it on the main road, in a no parking space. Leave this, I've once seen a Bounce parked on the Hosur Road flyover!This is a bounce parked in a private property. People have started parking in their apartments and the others cannot take them because the apartment security doesn't allow to. I literally had to fight with the security of an apartment to let me take the scooter even though it was the fault of someone in their building.Moreover, people ruthlessly steal helmets provided by Bounce for free which you can use and keep it back in the boot after you've finished the ride.Sorry to the owners of Bounce, but this business model is surely not gonna work in India. We Indians don't deserve something like this.The idea is amazing though. It should be tried in other countries like Japan where this could be managed much better!Image source - Google.Edit -In these scooters supposedly the battery and GPS system is removed so the company probably can't track it (Not sure, if anyone knows they can tell me in comments)How much does a helmet cost? Free in Bangalore :) (This guy stole the Bounce helmet and using for his own bike)Why just the tires and battery? Could've stolen the entire scooter!

But with the advent of mobile operating systems streamlined for the basic smartphone specifications (Firefox OS,Ubuntu phone) along with many interested manufacturers (ZTE, Huawei) who are ready to cater to the needs of this large and hungry demographic, it will be a matter of just a few months before you see some REALLY cheap smart phones.Ubuntu for phones | Ubuntu2) Wearable Gadgets:Going by CES 2013, A deluge of smartwatches and fitness accessories is about to hit the stores soon. All waiting to be connected and synced to your phone, tablet or laptop.3) Rise of HTML5 (finally!):3) Rise of HTML5 (finally!):Get ready for an influx of elegant, interactive, immersive, content rich web experience. And guess what, your desktop and mobile browsers (Firefox, Chrome, Safari, Opera, IE) are already primed and ready to make the most of it.HTML5 is also the most mobile ready tool for developing mobile sites and apps. With Adobe announcing the death of mobile Flash, you will now count on HTML5 to do your mobile web application development.HTML5 is also the most mobile ready tool for developing mobile sites and apps. With Adobe announcing the death of mobile Flash, you will now count on HTML5 to do your mobile web application development.4) A giant step forward in building the future 'Smart' homes:Smart homes are not ready yet. But 2013 will be a major step forward in building a connected 'Smart' home. The pieces are already moving into place with the current line up of (much exaggerated)This year will see an increase in the number of everyday devices with better connectivity ( through WiFi, Bluetooth and cellular networks) to the Web and also with each other. A few innovations for your living room are eagerly anticipated in 2013 as well (Apple TV?).5) HD voice (wideband audio):HD voice delivers higher quality voice transmissions, providing users with more natural sounding speech. It has already been deployed in most developed countries but i am taking a gamble and saying HD Voice will become an industry standard with most handsets (iPhone 5 is already HD voice ready) and carriers adopting it. By the year end the phone manufacturers and carriers should be labeling it indispensable.

Answer: There are two types of step forward. The first is iterative, with reasonable visibility of the steps ahead, as they rely on the application of known technologies. Think mobile phones, which every year have more pixels, more power, smaller bezels and longer battery life.The second is what Peter Thiel calls “Zero to One” thinking, with at least one new idea which cannot be predicted. This means no-one can be sure of the time scale. Think, for example of flying cars, which looked an imminent possibility in the fifties, but still haven’t arrived.There is also a third factor - acceptance. Often theThere are two types of step forward. The first is iterative, with reasonable visibility of the steps ahead, as they rely on the application of known technologies. Think mobile phones, which every year have more pixels, more power, smaller bezels and longer battery life.The second is what Peter Thiel calls “Zero to One” thinking, with at least one new idea which cannot be predicted. This means no-one can be sure of the time scale. Think, for example of flying cars, which looked an imminent possibility in the fifties, but still haven’t arrived.There is also a third factor - acceptance. Often the technology jump is easy, but the human one is not. Often things take a generation to move from fear-driven resistance to acceptance, with a view to the future possibilities and next steps. It may also take a recession to sweep away the old and make way for the new.
